author: By Ana Ionova and Jack Nicas
title: Lula Recovering From Emergency Surgery for Bleeding in Skull
description: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil was in the hospital following the procedure. Doctors said the bleeding appeared to be linked to a fall in October.
content: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil was in stable condition on Tuesday and recovering in an intensive care unit after emergency surgery to ease bleeding in his skull that doctors believe is connected to a fall he suffered at home in October, the doctors treating him said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: connotation
description: This word has appeared in 37 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word connotation has appeared in 37 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 28 in “Peridot Is the ‘Brat’ Green of Gems” by Victoria Gomelsky:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanna Notte
title: Putin Just Suffered a Huge Defeat
description: This time, when Bashar al-Assad started to fall, Russia was not there to catch him.
content: This time, when Bashar al-Assad started to fall, Russia was not there to catch him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By W.J. Hennigan and Derek Arthur
title: The Security Threat Hundreds of Miles Above Our Heads
description: Nuclear war in space could have catastrophic consequences for life on Earth. President-elect Trump must do everything in his power to prevent it.
content: What would happen if a nuclear weapon detonated in space, destroying the satellites that make so much of our digital existence — and our national security — possible? In this episode, William Hennigan, the lead writer for Times Opinion’s At the Brink series, speaks with the man whose job is to make sure that never happens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Maglaque
title: What Were the Lives of Medieval Women Like?
description: In “Poet, Mystic, Widow, Wife” the historian Hetta Howes seeks to relate to figures of the past.
content: “Do you not realize that Eve is you?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 548
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Dec. 10, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Martial Law Fallout Raises Questions South Korea Has Never Dealt With Before
description: The president faces an accusation of insurrection and, in a first for a sitting leader, the possibility of arrest. Here’s what to know about his political future.
content: President Yoon Suk Yeol’s short-lived declaration of martial law and th​e​ ​ensuing political uncertainty ​have created a constitutional crisis like South Koreans haven’t seen ​since their country democratized in the late 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: 12 Days That Changed Syria: The Rebel Offensive in Visuals
description: A visual timeline of the stunning rebel advance in Syria
content: In just two weeks, rebel forces tore across Syria, shattering the stalemate left by more than a decade of civil war and bringing an end to more than five decades of brutal rule by the Assad dynasty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austyn Gaffney
title: As Teenagers, They Protested Trump’s Climate Policy. Now What?
description: Some young climate activists who were galvanized under Donald Trump’s first presidency are taking a different approach to his second.
content: The youth climate movement that formed under the first Trump presidency is gearing up for his second.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. Transfers $20 Billion Loan to Ukraine Backed by Russian Assets
description: The economic lifeline ensures that Ukraine will have economic support after President-elect Donald J. Trump takes office.
content: The Biden administration transferred $20 billion to Ukraine on Tuesday, providing an urgently needed economic lifeline in the form of a loan that will be repaid using interest earned from Russia’s frozen central bank assets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: The Search Ends
description: The police identified a suspect in the UnitedHealthcare killing. We explain what we know about him.
content: For five days, the man who killed a health insurance C.E.O. on a Manhattan street seemed to have vanished. But yesterday morning, a McDonald’s employee in Altoona, Pa., noticed a familiar-looking young man eating a meal and called the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ismaeel Naar, Eric Lipton, David Yaffe-Bellany and Tamir Kalifa
title: Eric Trump Promises the ‘Most Pro-Crypto President’ in History
description: Speaking at a Middle East conference, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s son said his family had embraced cryptocurrency because some banks stopped doing business with them after Jan. 6.
content: Eric Trump flew across the world to headline a cryptocurrency conference in the United Arab Emirates this week and told thousands of enthusiastic attendees that he and his father, the U.S. president-elect, were effectively working in tandem to push crypto, a business sector the family is directly invested in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker, Mike Isaac and Aric Toler
title: Suspect in CEO’s Killing Had Discussed His Health Struggles on Reddit
description: In posts that stretch over years, he described debilitating back pain, “brain fog” in his college years and testing for irritable bowel syndrome.
content: The man charged in the killing of the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare reported in online writings over a period of years that he had been navigating a series of life-altering health problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: What to Know About Syria’s Notorious Sednaya Prison
description: Amnesty International described it as a “human slaughterhouse,” where, other rights groups say, tens of thousands of people were detained, tortured and killed during the 13-year civil war.
content: As the Assad regime in Syria crumbled over the weekend, the conquering rebels threw open the gates to the prisons where the government had detained tens of thousands of its people, torturing and killing them on an industrial scale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Health Panel Endorses New Option for Cervical Cancer Screening
description: Starting at 30, women can collect their own vaginal samples for HPV testing at a doctor’s office.
content: Doctors routinely advise that women undergoing screening for cervical cancer receive Pap smears every three years beginning at age 21. Now, beginning at 30, women have a new option.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Nicole Tung
title: A Tour of Assad’s Monumental Palace, With a Scruffy Rebel as a Guide
description: The televisions may be stripped away now, but a presidential residence still contains many remnants of a brutal reign.
content: Red carpets still run down the airy hallways of the mountaintop presidential palace in the Syrian capital, Damascus. Large chandeliers hang in ornate reception rooms filled with wooden Damascene furniture. Modernist sculptures remain in place in offices and sitting rooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson and Amy Chang Chien
title: Taiwan Says China Has Deployed Largest Fleet of Ships in Decades
description: Taiwan is on high alert in response to China’s unannounced deployment of naval and Coast Guard ships, as tensions rise over U.S. support for the island.
content: Taiwan said on Tuesday that China was conducting its largest maritime operations in nearly three decades, sending nearly 90 naval and coast guard vessels into waters stretching from the southern Japanese islands to the South China Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Graff and Judson Jones
title: A ‘Particularly Dangerous Situation’ for Fire Weather Is Unfolding
description: Strong winds have created a fast-moving and hot blaze, forecasters said, and the conditions are expected to continue into the evening.
content: The Franklin fire is burning so hot that it has modified the local winds, bending them toward and into the fire overnight, forecasters out of the National Weather Service in Los Angeles said on Tuesday morning, as they warned that the wind conditions that helped fuel it are expected to continue through much of the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: A Filmmaker, a Spy and France’s Richest Man Meet in a Paris Court
description: Bernard Arnault, the head of LVMH, squared off with a documentary maker in a case of espionage gone wrong, a showdown that had been brewing for years.
content: François Ruffin had just started filming a satirical documentary about Bernard Arnault, France’s richest man and head of the LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton luxury conglomerate, when he became suspicious about a volunteer on his staff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devlin Barrett
title: Trump Picks Strident Supporter for Civil Rights Post at Justice Dept.
description: Harmeet K. Dhillon has been a conservative activist so devoted to the president-elect that she was willing to attack not only Democrats but also fellow Republicans.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Monday that he would nominate Harmeet K. Dhillon, a California lawyer who has long championed Mr. Trump in public, in court cases and on social media, to run the Justice Department’s Civil Rights Division.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronica Chambers
title: When Nikki Giovanni Was Young, Brilliant and Unafraid
description: The poet set the course for her revolutionary career early, and charted it faithfully for decades by staying true to her vision and herself.
content: There’s a clip of Nikki Giovanni and James Baldwin that keeps popping up on TikTok. The year was 1971. It was a little more than three years after the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr. Richard M. Nixon was president and nowhere close to resigning. “Theme From Shaft” was No. 1 on the Billboard charts, “Imagine” by John Lennon was No. 6 and “Got to Be There” by Michael Jackson was No. 7. Nikki Giovanni was 28 years old, Baldwin was 47, and the two writers met in London to film a conversation for a public television series, “Soul!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Markovits
title: A Novel Inspired by Images of a Young Prisoner at Auschwitz
description: In “The Rest Is Memory,” Lily Tuck imagines the life of a Polish teenager during the Holocaust.
content: Lily Tuck has range. She has written historical fiction set in South America — her novel “The News From Paraguay” won the National Book Award in 2004 — and low-key realist short stories about contemporary life. These works move with ease and a kind of persuasive expat familiarity between the south of France; Thailand; Cambridge, Mass.; and a dude ranch in Nevada. Her prose style shifts with the subject matter but has also gotten leaner over time; it runs closer to the bone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Mayor Adams’s Stance on Migrants Has Evolved, in Trump’s Direction
description: Mayor Eric Adams has become more outspoken about his desire to detain “dangerous” immigrants, a view more closely aligned with President-elect Donald J. Trump.
content: Over the past two years, Mayor Eric Adams has made no secret of his frustrations with New York City’s migrant crisis. But after President-elect Donald J. Trump’s victory, the mayor’s criticism has taken a sharper turn to the right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon, Mike Baker, Luke Broadwater and Shawn Hubler
title: Suspect in C.E.O. Killing Withdrew From a Life of Privilege and Promise
description: The suspect, Luigi Mangione, was an Ivy League tech graduate from a prominent Maryland family who in recent months had suffered physical and psychological pain.
content: Luigi Mangione, the online version of him, was an Ivy League tech enthusiast who flaunted his tanned, chiseled looks in beach photos and party pictures with blue-blazered frat buddies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Says Trump’s Tax Cuts and Tariffs Would Be ‘a Major Mistake’
description: The president also said his successor would face blowback from the Republican Party if he tried to unwind the Biden agenda.
content: President Biden said on Tuesday that President-elect Donald J. Trump’s plans to impose tax cuts for the wealthy and sweeping tariffs would be “a major mistake,” while warning that the incoming president would face blowback from Republicans if he moved to unwind the Biden agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold and Camille Baker
title: Fund-Raiser Who Pocketed Money Meant for Sick Kids and Vets Gets 10 Years in Prison
description: Richard Zeitlin, a telemarketing kingpin who kept 80 percent of the donations raised for charities, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit wire fraud in September.
content: If you owned a phone in America over the last 40 years, there is a good chance you got a call from Richard L. Zeitlin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Machkovech
title: Netflix’s Surprising Selection of Free Video Games
description: A Netflix subscription gives you access to hit games like Into the Breach and Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas, along with TV tie-ins like Squid Game: Unleashed.
content: Three years ago, Netflix introduced a perk in an attempt to stand out from the cord-cutting fray: video games. Subscribers can pick from a variety of smartphone games and play them for no additional charge, each free of advertisements, microtransactions and other typical nuisances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: McConnell Sprained Wrist During a Fall but Is ‘Fine’
description: Senator Mitch McConnell, the minority leader who sustained a concussion in a fall last year, was cleared to resume his work schedule, according to his office.
content: Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky and the minority leader, tripped and fell following the weekly Senate Republicans lunch on Tuesday, spraining his wrist and sustaining a small cut to his face, a spokesman said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: South Korea’s President Is Still in Office. This Man Intends to Push Him Out.
description: Lee Jae-myung, the main opposition leader, is leading efforts to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol over his declaration of martial law. He could also be the next president.
content: Shortly after his political nemesis, President Yoon Suk Yeol, declared martial law last Tuesday, Lee Jae-myung began livestreaming from his cellphone. While driving to the National assembly, the leader of South Korea’s main opposition party appealed to Koreans to rush to the assembly and hold back soldiers trying to seize the Parliament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Six Arrested in Connection With Deadly Accident That Killed Over 50 Migrants
description: U.S. and Guatemalan authorities said the arrests were linked to a human trafficking ring and a deadly 2021 traffic accident.
content: Five people in Guatemala and one in Texas were arrested on Monday on human smuggling charges linked to one of the deadliest traffic accidents involving migrants in recent history, U.S. and Guatemalan officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Vik Jolly
title: Many Evacuated, but Some Malibu Residents Broke Out the Hoses
description: Thousands of people were told to flee their homes in Malibu, Calif., as the Franklin fire approached. But a few stayed behind, using garden hoses to protect their property and themselves.
content: The flames came suddenly in the middle of the night, and the evacuation orders swiftly followed. Thousands of residents were told to leave their homes immediately and flee for their lives as wind gusts quickly turned a fire into a raging inferno in the hills above Malibu, Calif.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing and Eli Tan
title: G.M. Will Stop Developing Self-Driving Taxis
description: The company said it would now focus its efforts on developing fully autonomous vehicles for personal use.
content: General Motors said on Tuesday that it would stop developing a taxi that can drive itself, ending a yearslong project that the company spent billions of dollars on and leaving the field to competitors like Tesla, Amazon and Waymo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: Biden Administration Sprints to Tie Up Tech Loose Ends
description: Regulators are working around the clock to cement four years of tech policy ahead of the inauguration of President-elect Donald J. Trump.
content: After last month’s presidential election, Lina Khan, the Democratic chair of the Federal Trade Commission, went into turbo mode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Hear the Best Albums and Songs of 2024
description: A playlist of 103 songs from our three critics’ lists to experience however you wish.
content: Here at The Amplifier, we like to keep our playlists relatively brief, like bite-sized musical snacks you can nosh on when you have some downtime. But each December, when the critics are publishing our best-of lists, we like to offer up a much heartier feast. Well, I hope your ears are hungry (is that how it works?) because today is the day. It’s time for our annual playlist of the year’s best music — more than six hours and slightly over 100 tracks of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Trunk of the Body
description: Brian Callahan and Geoffrey Schorkopf have their first Times collaboration.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Trump Calls Trudeau the ‘Governor’ of ‘The Great State of Canada’
description: The president-elect’s mockery of Canada and its leader is the latest salvo after his promise to impose steep tariffs on Canadian exports.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump mocked Canada’s prime minister in a post late Monday that described him as “Governor Justin Trudeau of the Great State of Canada.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Kennedy’s War on Corn Syrup Brings a Health Crusade to Trump Country
description: When Donald J. Trump said Robert F. Kennedy Jr. could “go wild” on health, he might not have expected his pick for health secretary doing battle against the president-elect’s own voters.
content: The Archer Daniels Midland wet mill on the outskirts of Decatur, Ill., rises like an industrial behemoth from the frozen, harvested cornfields of Central Illinois. Steam billowed in the 20-degree cold last week, as workers turned raw corn into sweet, ubiquitous high-fructose corn syrup. Three miles away, a Primient mill, which sprawls across 400 acres divided by North 22nd Street, was doing the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: It’s Ariana Grande vs. Selena Gomez at the Oscars, at Least in Fans’ Minds
description: Stan armies are waging war over which pop star is the “better” actor. Movie lovers used to awards-season maneuvering haven’t seen anything like this.
content: Anyone who follows the Oscar race knows it can get nasty. Over the long arc of awards season, films can fall in and out of favor, villains can emerge, and campaigns can be ferocious in their pursuit of gold statues. But movie fans aren’t used to the vitriol that comes along with pop music. Now, they are getting a taste.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Quantum Computing Inches Closer
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, December 10, 2024.
content: “What has happened over the last year shows that it is no longer science fiction.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Duehren
title: At ‘Tax Prom,’ Washington Prepares for More Tax Cuts
description: Republican control of Washington and a tax bill next year have corporate America excited — and on edge.
content: Life was good for the tuxedoed and gowned tax lobbyists lined up last month along Washington’s waterfront to get into “Tax Prom,” a wonky event even by the standards of a city peopled by policy nerds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: FIFA Bends Own Rules to Give Saudi Arabia Coveted 2034 World Cup
description: Critics objected to the bidding process, and human rights groups raised concerns about workplace safety for the migrants who will build the stadiums needed to host the event.
content: Under its de facto leader, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, Saudi Arabia has unleashed a spending spree on global sports, turning the kingdom into a contender for the biggest events.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 10, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Dec. 10, 2024.
content: An article on Saturday about Lebanon and Jordan closing border crossings with Syria misidentified the source of a warning given to Americans to leave Syria promptly. It came from the U.S. State Department, not from the U.S. Embassy in Damascus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jameel Jaffer and Genevieve Lakier
title: The Supreme Court Must Intervene in the TikTok Case
description: The First Amendment should not be used to cut Americans’ access to TikTok, and the Supreme Court should step in.
content: Last week, the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit upheld a federal law that threatens to shut down TikTok in the United States. The court’s most consequential conclusion: The First Amendment permits the government to protect Americans from covert foreign manipulation by restricting their access to foreign-controlled media — even when that means Americans’ speech is restricted, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells, Melissa Clark and Priya Krishna
title: New York’s 14 Best New Restaurants of 2024
description: Our three critics name the places, from classic French dining to a buzzing shawarma stall, that dazzled them the most this year.
content: Stop me if you’ve heard this one: Three critics walk into a restaurant …
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz, Kate Christobek and Sara Ruberg
title: Hate Crime Charges Dropped Against Most Salisbury U. Students Who Were Arrested
description: Hate crime charges against at least 12 of the 15 Maryland students accused of assaulting a person because of his sexual orientation have been dismissed, court records show. They still face misdemeanor counts.
content: Prosecutors have dropped hate crime charges against 12 of the 15 Salisbury University students who the police said had lured a person to an off-campus apartment through a dating app and then repeatedly beat and spat on him because of his sexual orientation, according to court records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Dionne Searcey, Maria Cramer, Stella Tan, Alex Stern, Lynsea Garrison, Nina Feldman, Luke Vander Ploeg, Paige Cowett, Maria Byrne, Diane Wong, Elisheba Ittoop, Pat McCusker, Sophia Lanman and Chris Wood
title: The Manhunt, the Manifesto and the Murder Charge
description: What we know about the suspect arrested in the shooting of UnitedHealthcare’s chief executive.
content: Last week, the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare was shot and killed in Manhattan. A five-day search for the gunman ensued.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: That Manhunt Photo Looks Like a Loved One. Do You Have to Tell?
description: Photos of the suspect in the killing of the UnitedHealthcare C.E.O. were circulated by the police and viewed by millions of Americans, making it likely that at least a few people who saw them recognized him.
content: If someone you know is the subject of a nationwide manhunt and the authorities are desperately trying to learn the person’s name, are you under any legal obligation to come forward with it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: What Can We Learn From the C.E.O. Shooting Suspect’s Goodreads History?
description: Like many Americans of his background, Luigi Mangione’s bookish aspirations were defined by what everybody else was reading, or thought they should be reading.
content: Luigi Mangione read “The Lorax” and “How to Break Up With Your Phone,” Hawaiian travel guides and books about spinal health. Among his favorites were “The Four-Hour Work Week” and “Brave New World.” Earlier this year, he wrote a measured, four-star review of “Industrial Society and Its Future,” better known as the Unabomber Manifesto, praising the author’s insight while noting that he had been “rightfully imprisoned” for his violent actions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Frog Club Ends Life as It Began: Strangely
description: The lurid collapse of its chef’s previous project fueled a fascination that made the New York restaurant impossible to get into. Or so it seemed for a while.
content: Froggy, we hardly knew ye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: New York to Close Giant Family Shelter to Protect Migrants From Trump
description: The imminent closure reflects concern from New York City officials that President-elect Donald J. Trump will target the shelter because it sits on federal land.
content: New York City officials announced on Tuesday that they would close a giant tent complex in Brooklyn that houses some 2,000 migrants, a pre-emptive step meant to fend off concerns that the shelter could be targeted by the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti, Katie Glueck and Reid J. Epstein
title: Resist Trump? On Immigration, Top Democrats See Room for Compromise.
description: In interviews, a range of Democratic governors expressed some defiance toward the president-elect’s expected crackdown, but also showed a surprising willingness to work with him.
content: As President-elect Donald J. Trump promises to deport millions of undocumented immigrants, Democratic governors are bracing themselves to be on the front lines of an emotional and politically explosive battle against his administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Do I Really Need to Throw Out My Black Plastic Spatula?
description: A new study detected dangerous chemicals in a variety of household items. But experts say the health risks aren’t clear-cut.
content: Q: I have a few black plastic kitchen utensils in my drawer, but I’ve read that they’re dangerous. Is that true?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: What to Know About the Countries Still Dropping Bombs in Syria
description: Bashar al-Assad is gone, and Russia and Iran have stepped back. But Israel, Turkey and the United States are carrying out airstrikes.
content: Great powers have fought for centuries for influence in the territory known today as Syria, each seeing a prize in its strategic position, stretching from the Mediterranean Sea to the Euphrates River and beyond. That struggle continues today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft
title: Pepperdine Students Huddled in Library as Malibu Fire Raged Outside
description: About 3,000 people sheltered on the university’s campus in Malibu, Calif., overnight on Monday. Some of them watched the flames through the windows of a library.
content: As flames roared and smoke billowed around their campus, the students gathered in the library at Pepperdine University prayed for safety. They donned masks as acrid smoke filtered into the building. They watched anxiously through the windows as the flames drew closer and even consumed some of the palm trees that dot the scenic Malibu campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: Storm King to Begin 2025 With Nora Lawrence as Executive Director
description: The family-run Hudson Valley sculpture park inaugurates its 65th anniversary year with fresh leadership, a $53-million upgrade and new acquisitions.
content: Storm King Art Center, the 500-acre outdoor museum, announced on Tuesday that Nora Lawrence, its artistic director and chief curator, will succeed its president, John P. Stern, as the institution’s leader in January. It also announced a series of commissions and acquisitions, and a solo show by the Brazilian visual artist Sonia Gomes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Chaundler
title: These Nuns Were Excommunicated but Won’t Leave Their Convents
description: The Poor Clares of Belorado, in northern Spain, are digging in their heels in a battle of wills over real estate with the Catholic Church.
content: One afternoon this past summer, a car sped out of the gates of a convent on the outskirts of a sleepy village in northern Spain and kept going until it reached another convent 85 miles away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leanne Abraham, Lazaro Gamio and John Keefe
title: See How the Franklin Fire Surrounded Malibu as It Quickly Grew
description: See maps and details about the Franklin fire near Los Angeles.
content: A wildfire in Malibu, Calif., forced evacuations, destroyed homes and burned more than 3,000 acres along the Pacific coastline as of Tuesday night, California fire officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: In France, Marine Le Pen Takes Aim at the Top
description: After helping to oust the prime minister last week, the far-right leader has made clear her next target is President Emmanuel Macron.
content: The one-on-one duel that has shaped French political life for nearly a decade ratcheted up a notch last week, with the far-right leader Marine Le Pen claiming one big scalp, and giving notice of going after a bigger one, President Emmanuel Macron.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Nikki Giovanni, Poet Who Wrote of Black Joy, Dies at 81
description: As a writer, she tackled race, gender, sex, politics and love. She was also a public intellectual who appeared on television and toured the country.
content: Nikki Giovanni, the charismatic and iconoclastic poet, activist, children’s book author and professor who wrote, irresistibly and sensuously, about race, politics, gender, sex and love, died on Monday in Blacksburg, Va. She was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: How to Understand the Armed Factions Operating in Syria
description: The fighters shared a desire to topple Bashar al-Assad’s government, but they don’t share much else.
content: Rebel forces have swept through Syria and forced former President Bashar al-Assad out of the country where his family had ruled with an iron fist since the early 1970s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Arctic Tundra Has Long Helped Cool Earth. Now, It’s Fueling Warming.
description: Wildfires and thawing permafrost are causing the region to release more carbon dioxide than its plants remove, probably for the first time in thousands of years.
content: For thousands of years, the shrubs, sedges, mosses and lichens of the Arctic have performed a vital task for the planet: gulping down carbon dioxide from the air and storing the carbon in their tissues. When the plants die, this carbon is entombed in the frigid soil, where it no longer helps warm Earth’s surface.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: How Crypto Insiders Turned ‘Debanking’ Into a Political Storm
description: Concerns that crypto companies are being purposely cut off from the global banking system have become a political cudgel at an opportune moment for the industry.
content: Early last year, Ryne Saxe started fielding demands from banks that worked with his San Francisco-based start-up, Eco. They laid out a litany of new compliance and reporting requirements that Eco had to follow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna, Melissa Clark and Pete Wells
title: Hungry for the Best? Here Are Our Top New York Dishes of 2024.
description: A messy patty melt, an exemplary chocolate cake and two dozen other delights worth savoring.
content: Among the hundreds, if not thousands, of bites that restaurant critics take each year, there are some that suddenly make us sit up straighter, sharper and happier. These are the dishes that linger in our brains all the way home, that inspire obsessions over what exactly was going on in the kitchen to make those ingredients taste this good. They can be as simple as an ethereal tortilla or as elaborate as a deeply spiced, banquet-worthy chicken biryani.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Sarah Jessica Parker Lands Her Dream Gig: Booker Prize Judge
description: The actress and publisher will help decide the 2025 winner of the prestigious British book award. It is “the thrill of a life,” she said.
content: On New Year’s Eve 2022, Sarah Jessica Parker was scrolling on Instagram when she saw a video by the Booker Prize, the prestigious British literary award, in which three judges talked about the craziness of reading 170 novels in seven months to pick that year’s nominees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Jamie Foxx on His Stroke and Other Life-Changing Moments in ‘What Had Happened Was …’
description: The show is both an act of gratitude and a stand-up special. It’s one of four new comedy hours worth checking out.
content: The latest batch of comedy specials worth watching starts with a much anticipated one from Jamie Foxx and includes hours from Matthew Broussard, Anthony Jeselnik and Fortune Feimster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Hutchinson
title: Winter Workout Tips, From Scientists Who Study Extreme Cold
description: A few tweaks to your routine can make getting outside more comfortable this season.
content: With cold weather, icy streets and shorter days, it’s easy to find an excuse to stay inside during the winter months. That’s presumably why Americans on average get about half an hour less daily physical activity at this time of year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum and Emily Schmall
title: The Debilitating Toll of Back Pain
description: The suspect charged with killing the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare was said to have back issues, one of the most common medical problems nationwide.
content: Friends of the 26-year-old charged with killing the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare have said he was dealing with back issues that led to sometimes debilitating pain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Dick Van Dyke and Cher Flee Their Malibu Homes as Franklin Fire Burns
description: Mr. Van Dyke, who turns 99 on Friday, said that he and his wife, Arlene, had fled their home with their pets as the Franklin fire threatened their community.
content: Malibu, Calif., has long occupied a particular place in the American imagination, a sun-soaked paradise of coastal bluffs and crashing waves. It is also home to the rich and famous: Dick Van Dyke, Cher and Barbra Streisand are among the many stars who live there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko and Anusha Bayya
title: In Penny Verdict, a Flashpoint in the Debate Over Crime and Mental Illness
description: A New York jury acquitted Daniel Penny in the death of Jordan Neely. Republican politicians hailed the verdict. But some New Yorkers found it deeply disturbing.
content: Outside the Manhattan criminal courthouse on Monday, a scuffle broke out among demonstrators, their chants amplified over bullhorns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Aaron Boxerman
title: Netanyahu Finally Takes the Stand in His Corruption Trial
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is accused of bribery, fraud and breach of trust in a trial that began four years ago. He has denied the charges.
content: Outside the courthouse, he is one of the most powerful men in the Middle East, overseeing Israel’s military campaign in Gaza, its occupation of southern Lebanon and recent strikes in Syria.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Edmund Lee and Sapna Maheshwari
title: How Murdoch Could Fight Back After a Big Legal Defeat
description: Rupert Murdoch lost a bid to rewrite a family trust to give his son Lachlan control of his empire after he dies. But the nonagenarian media titan plans to appeal.
content: Rupert Murdoch has lost his bid to hand control over his media company to his elder son, Lachlan Murdoch, after he dies. A Nevada commissioner ruled against his attempt to modify the terms of a family trust that would have stripped three of his other children of their voting rights over his empire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: With an Eye on China, Australia Strikes a Deal With Nauru
description: In return for financial support, the Pacific island nation of Nauru pledged not to enter any security pacts without Australia’s assent.
content: Australia has signed a treaty with the Pacific island nation of Nauru to provide aid, banking and other infrastructure support, the latest maneuvering for influence in the region between China and countries allied with the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: A Chic ’70s Vibe in the Desert, Complete With Gems and Crystals
description: Two brothers and a designer created a development company in Pioneertown, Calif., to bring the local natural beauty to the old places that needed it.
content: Matt French was working in urban development in Portland, Ore., 10 years ago when he took a trip to Joshua Tree, Calif., and realized he wanted to do something else with his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe and Joshua Barone
title: Best Classical Performances of 2024
description: Standouts included the soprano Lise Davidsen and the Berlin Philharmonic, a new opera by Missy Mazzoli and bits of old ones by Schubert.
content: The joy of a music critic’s job is how wide the purview is. From revivals of centuries-old pieces to the premieres of brand-new works, the field I cover is an ecosystem that takes pride in both the past and the future. My favorite performances this year, in chronological order, spanned eras, but all were marriages of imaginative spontaneity and meticulous craft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: A day after the regime of President Bashar al-Assad fell, civilians poured into the streets of Damascus, Syria, some weeping in disbelief. Many sought word of relatives held in a notorious prison on the outskirts of the city. Others clambered on top of cars and screamed curses at the Assad family, words that days ago could have meant a death sentence. Here’s the latest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Notre Dame Reopens
description: Have you ever visited? Would you like to? What’s your favorite architectural masterpiece?
content: Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris reopened this weekend, more than five years after a devastating fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Suspect in C.E.O. Killing Fights Extradition
description: Also, a wildfire roared into Malibu. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: The 26-year-old man who was charged with murder in the assassination of a health insurance executive in Midtown Manhattan was denied bail today. The suspect, Luigi Mangione, is fighting extradition to New York, meaning that he could spend the next several weeks at a prison in Pennsylvania near the city where he was arrested. Here’s the latest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: Monarch Butterflies Are Recommended for Protected Status
description: They would become the most commonly seen species to receive federal protection if the proposal is adopted.
content: Federal wildlife officials proposed on Tuesday that monarch butterflies receive protection as a threatened species.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The Syria Opportunity
description: The end of al-Assad’s wretched regime unlocks many doors.
content: How can the United States take advantage of the great but tricky strategic opportunity that the fall of Bashar al-Assad’s tyranny in Damascus offers us? Mainly through a combination of meaningful incentives for, and credible threats against, our enemies, frenemies, allies and would-be friends. Let’s go down the list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman
title: In Georgia Protests, Echoes of Ukraine’s Past Revolutions
description: This former Soviet Republic has been rocked by anti-government demonstrations over the same issues that hurtled Ukraine into war — its relationship with Europe and Russia.
content: On the streets of Georgia, it’s starting to look a little like the Ukraine of 10 years ago, before the war, when tensions with Russia started brewing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: French Court Finds Writer Guilty of Denying Rwandan Genocide
description: Charles Onana and his publisher were fined for passages in a book that were found to have violated a French law making it illegal to deny an officially recognized genocide.
content: A court in Paris has found a writer and his publisher guilty of denying the 1994 Rwandan genocide, apparently a first under French law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Best Comedy of 2024
description: Jon Stewart made “The Daily Show” must-see TV again, Theo Von had a memorable moment with Donald Trump, and Nikki Glaser broke through.
content: Joe Rogan jumped to the front of the conservative media establishment. Netflix went in deeper on live comedy, while Disney entered the stand-up market. Katt Williams beefed even more than Kendrick Lamar and Drake. John Mulaney and Taylor Tomlinson became talk show hosts. It was an eventful year in comedy. Here are some highlights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: Finance Moguls Revel in Trump’s Return and Ignore the Peril
description: The financial world sees plenty of opportunity in the return of President-elect Donald J. Trump. For now, Wall Streeters are looking past the risks.
content: The day after the presidential election, JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, Jamie Dimon, picked up his phone for a call he had hoped not to make.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should Biden Issue Pre-emptive Pardons?
description: Readers discuss a column by Michelle Goldberg and an editorial. Also: Farewell, Paul Krugman; jeopardizing jobs; hating and fearing death.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Debate Over Hegseth’s Fitness Highlights a Gender Divide in the Senate
description: As many of the Senate’s Republican men dismiss allegations against President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Pentagon, only a small group of G.O.P. women have voiced even a hint of skepticism.
content: Appearing from within the echo chamber of Fox News, Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina last week batted away the sexual assault and misconduct allegations dogging Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to lead the Defense Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: An Installation That May Give Way to a Casino
description: The developer of a site near the U.N. plans a temporary “Path of Liberty” installation while he awaits a casino decision.
content: Good morning. Today we’ll look at a plan for the latest interactive installation near the United Nations on a site that could become a casino. We’ll also get details on the suspect in the fatal shooting of a health insurance executive on a Midtown street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: A Northern Gaza Hospital Lacks Food and Water for Patients, Officials Say
description: The health ministry in Gaza said dozens of patients are at risk of death because the Indonesian Hospital does not have enough water and food to keep them alive.
content: Dozens of wounded patients in a hospital in the northern Gaza Strip are in danger of dying because of a dire absence of basic supplies like food and water, according to local health authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Lights Dim on the Friars Club as Landmark Home Is Sold in Foreclosure
description: The six-story Manhattan townhouse, once the stomping ground of America’s comic legends, was sold at an auction on Tuesday for $17.2 million.
content: For decades, New York’s Friars Club, the seat of American comedy and legendary roasts, has made its home in a landmark building on Manhattan’s East Side. That era appeared to end on Tuesday, not with a punchline and a rimshot, but with a foreclosure auction in which the club’s townhouse was sold to a creditor for $17.2 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Faye Tsakas
title: How Being an Influencer Became a New American Dream
description: Two preteen girls promote fashion and beauty products to thousands of online fans from their rural Alabama home.
content: Whenever I browse social media, I see advice and products for self-improvement — a deluge of elusive promises tethered to consumer goods. How to look more angular or more toned, feel more energized, age backward. Capitalism and modern technology have mixed to create an internet world where users are transformed into brands. As a filmmaker, I’m drawn to document this culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Michael White Returns With Santi in a Familiar Space
description: Chez Fifi serves tastes of Spain by way of Paris, Fleur brings Shanghainese to Park Slope and more restaurant news.
content: The chef Michael White’s influence remained on several restaurants for years after he left New York to pursue opportunities in Florida, the Bahamas and elsewhere with his BBianco Hospitality Group. Now he’s back in the same location as Alto, his former flagship. Italy is his focus in a space with several dining areas done in neutral tones. Pastas like busiate with saffron and uni, and garganelli with Nantucket bay scallops; crudos, including one with Montauk red shrimp; and plates of pan-roasted squab, monkfish with speck, and a veal chop that pays homage to his years at San Domenico, in Italy, highlight the menu. (Opens Thursday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: Where Beards Grow, Strong Feelings Follow
description: Whether on Prince William, JD Vance or Jacob Elordi, facial hair gets people talking.
content: As far as beards go, his is more measly than grizzly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard, Rawan Sheikh Ahmad, Qasim Nauman and Thomas Fuller
title: Syria’s New Leaders Vow Punishment for Atrocities Under al-Assad
description: The rebels who seized Damascus are trying to get a new government up and running, even as foreign powers like Israel and Turkey, and armed Syrian groups, fight for power.
content: The rebel alliance that overthrew the Assad government in Syria vowed on Tuesday to hunt down and punish senior officials of the previous regime who are implicated in torture and other abuses, but said that rank-and-file conscripted soldiers would receive amnesty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell
title: Police in Worcester, Mass., Engaged in Sexual Misconduct, Justice Dept. Says
description: The agency found that the Police Department used excessive force and allowed undercover officers to have sexual contact with women suspected of being prostitutes.
content: A two-year investigation by the Justice Department found patterns of “outrageous” conduct by the police in Worcester, Mass., including excessive use of force and sexual contact between undercover officers and women suspected of prostitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Turns Up Its Nose at Trump’s Cologne Ad
description: The president-elect used a photo of Jill Biden smiling at him to promote his fragrances. Jimmy Kimmel thinks that’s because Melania has never smiled at him on camera.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austyn Gaffney
title: How the Climate Movement Is Changing Tactics After Trump’s Win
description: Faced with a president-elect who has called global warming a “scam,” activists are changing their strategies and pushing a message of hope.
content: With about a month and a half left until the Trump administration takes over the White House, I called Bill McKibben, a journalist, author and activist, to ask where the climate movement goes next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Scott Bessent, Trump’s Pick for Treasury Secretary, Doesn’t Fit His Loyalist Mold
description: A hedge-fund titan who worked for George Soros. A deep-rooted Southerner with a fondness for high-end real estate. A gay man, married with children. Who is Scott Bessent?
content: A capitalist with a soft spot for royalty. A deep-rooted Southerner with a fondness for stylish New York locales. A gay man, married with children, who has embraced a Republican Party that has sometimes vilified elements, and individuals, of the L.G.B.T.Q. movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: The Netanyahu Corruption Trial, Explained
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel took the stand on Tuesday. Here’s what to know about the trial.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel took the stand on Tuesday in his corruption trial for the first time since it began in 2020, raising the stakes in a divisive case that has disrupted Israel’s political life for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: On Issue After Issue, Trump Promises the Moon. No Word on the Rocket.
description: The president-elect has made some of the most expansive campaign pledges in history. Some supporters fear that his bravado could undermine his ambitions.
content: In his own telling, President-elect Donald J. Trump wields magical powers to shape world events in ways others never could. The other day, during his first broadcast television network interview since his re-election, he even claimed to have prevented wars that no one knew were about to break out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: Australian Cyclist Pleads Guilty in Death of Wife, a Fellow Olympian
description: Rohan Dennis pleaded guilty this week to a lesser charge in the death of Melissa Hoskins last year, after he drove with her on the hood of a vehicle, the authorities said.
content: Rohan Dennis, an Olympic cyclist from Australia, pleaded guilty this week for his role in a vehicle incident that fatally injured his wife, Melissa Hoskins, also an Olympic cyclist, late last year, the local media reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: The Plight of the Palestinian Scientist
description: Four Palestinian researchers describe how conflict in Gaza and the West Bank has hindered their careers in science and medicine.
content: Pursuing a scientific career in the Palestinian territories has been fraught for decades. Then Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7, 2023, igniting a war in the Gaza Strip that has lasted for more than a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Rage Grows Over a Spate of Brutal Murders of Women in Kenya
description: Almost 100 women have been killed in the span of three months, the police say. Rights groups want President William Ruto to declare femicide a national crisis.
content: A university student was murdered, and her body dumped in a field. A long-distance Olympic runner died after she was severely burned in a gasoline attack. And a mother, her daughter and her niece were tortured and then killed, their mutilated bodies disposed of in different locations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Poised to Curb Scope of Environmental Reviews
description: Several justices indicated that a federal agency had complied with a federal law by issuing a 3,600-page report on the impact of a proposed railway in Utah.
content: The Supreme Court seemed prepared on Tuesday to rule that a federal agency had done enough to consider the environmental impact of a proposed 88-mile railway in Utah. Such a ruling could limit the scope of environmental reviews required by federal law in all sorts of settings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reece Taylor Williams and Gregory Cowles
title: Nikki Giovanni: A Life in Pictures
description: The poet left a long visual record of a career in the public sphere.
content: Nikki Giovanni, the Black Arts poet who died on Monday at the age of 81, catapulted to fame in her 20s and remained a celebrity for the rest of her life thanks to her charisma, her command and, not least, the colloquial power and wisdom of her language. In 1972 Ebony magazine declared her “a personality, a star,” and photographers seemingly agreed: Over the next five decades, as her poetry touched on love and politics, food and desire and Black joy, her pixie face and puckish smile became a familiar presence in newspapers and magazines, on television and on the covers of her books. To a degree remarkable for a poet Giovanni lived her life in the public eye, and left behind a trail of archival images documenting a career spent speaking to America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: The 16 Best Cookbooks of 2024
description: Encyclopedic approaches to plant-based cooking and to cookies, a TikToker’s debut and more, as tested by New York Times Cooking and the Food desk.
content: When so much of modern living forces us to peer down at a screen, there’s a lot to be said for a cookbook. It won’t blast you with blue light or exacerbate your tech neck; it won’t inundate you with notifications or unskippable ads. If you let it, it will feed you and whomever you choose, and the best ones do so with vibrant photography, clear instructions and an extra serving of whimsy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Police Arrest 3 After Deadly Explosion in the Netherlands
description: The blast, which the mayor of The Hague called an “unprecedented disaster,” killed six people on Saturday morning.
content: The police in The Hague said on Tuesday that they had arrested three people in connection with an explosion at an apartment building in the Dutch city over the weekend that killed at least six people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Tabler
title: Why al-Assad Fell
description: Understanding the factors that led to the Syrian regime’s collapse is key to putting the pieces of the country back together.
content: The extraordinary collapse of the Assad regime over the weekend is a historic victory for the Syrian people, who for over a half-century have suffered under the Assad family’s brutal authoritarian rule. It will undoubtedly pose challenges and create opportunities for the United States and its allies in the Middle East and beyond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: Here’s How Much Cleaner Energy Could Save America, in Lives and Money
description: Widespread adoption of heat pumps could prevent thousands of premature deaths and save billions on energy bills, according to a new analysis.
content: Electric heat pumps, the most affordable and energy efficient way to heat and cool homes, continue to outsell gas furnaces nationwide. They can also reduce outdoor pollution and, as a result, save lives, according to a report issued on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 549
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Dec. 11, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: U.S. Data Agency Blames Old Tech and Other Failures for Missteps
description: The Bureau of Labor Statistics, which tracks jobs and inflation, issued a report on what caused embarrassing episodes in which data was released improperly.
content: Outdated technology, inadequate funding and a failure to follow established procedures contributed to embarrassing missteps at the Bureau of Labor Statistics this year, a panel that examined the episodes said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Israel, Seeing an Opportunity, Demolishes Syria’s Military Assets
description: Israel capitalized on the power vacuum in Syria to bomb targets across the country, saying it aims to keep weapons away from extremists.
content: As soon as it became clear on Sunday that there would be regime change in neighboring Syria, Israel began a sweeping aerial campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Graff
title: Wildfire Conditions Are Expected to Ease by the End of the Week
description: Rising humidity and a breeze pushing moist air inland from the Pacific Ocean are expected lower the wildfire risk around Malibu, Calif., by Thursday, forecasters said.
content: Much of Southern California will remain at risk for wildfires through Wednesday, forecasters warned, as firefighters struggled to bring the quick-moving Franklin fire in Malibu, Calif., under control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: White House Threatens Biden Veto of Bipartisan Bill to Add New Judges
description: The legislation would create more than 60 new federal court seats over the next decade, giving the Trump White House a first shot at filling dozens of new vacancies.
content: White House officials on Tuesday said President Biden would veto a bipartisan measure creating 66 new federal judicial seats over the next three presidential administrations, stating that the measure the House is set to take up this week is “unnecessary to the efficient and effective administration of justice.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Chasing the $100 Lift Ticket: 6 Mountains Where You Can Ski for Less
description: The average price of a single-day lift ticket at a destination ski resort in the U.S. is $250, but there are plenty of smaller areas where getting on the slopes is much cheaper.
content: Every year, there seems to be a grim competition as to which North American mountain resorts will have the highest daily rate for a lift ticket: It’s scary times when $250 is the new average at marquee destinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Trump Has a New Favorite Foreign Leader. He’s Known as ‘the Madman.’
description: Javier Milei and the rebirth of austerity for the needy.
content: Javier Milei, the wild-haired Argentine president known by his supporters as “the madman,” has lately edged out Hungary’s Viktor Orban as the MAGA movement’s chief international inspiration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul McAdory
title: Don’t Worry About Whether Art Basel Is Cool
description: The annual global art fair in Miami featured a heady mélange of artists, gallerists, A-list celebrities, luxury brands and Mad Libs-esque collaborations among many of them.
content: The in crowd knows that Art Basel, the annual global art fair in Miami, isn’t exactly cool anymore, but they go anyway out of professional obligation, or because certain parties might be cool, or for the same reason people with no interest in football watch the Super Bowl: because it’s the Super Bowl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘It’s Not Me’ Review: Entering the Mind of Leos Carax
description: This personal film is a dynamic, even chaotic, collage of moments that bring the director back to his beginnings.
content: Love poem, restless dream, troubled history, alchemist’s scrapbook — Leos Carax’s “It’s Not Me” is pure cinema as it dances through its dense 42 minutes. He crafted this indelibly personal and eccentric film in response to a prompt he was given from the Pompidou Center in Paris: “Where are you at, Leos Carax?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: Picking Through a Ruined Palace, in the Name of Vengeance
description: The debris of fallen tyrannies like al-Assad’s often carries a lingering fascination.
content: The scenes of ordinary Syrians gleefully ransacking Bashar al-Assad’s residence in Damascus may be troubling, but they certainly are not unfamiliar. That’s how dictators fall, in a paroxysm of jubilation and score settling. Decades of living in fear abruptly end, and people rush out to shred the physical symbols of power and avarice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: Federal Judge Blocks $25 Billion Kroger-Albertsons Grocery Merger
description: The ruling, citing a potential loss of competition, was a victory for the Federal Trade Commission. Later, a Washington State judge blocked the deal on similar grounds.
content: The biggest grocery store merger in U.S. history was dealt a double blow on Tuesday: Within less than two hours, both a federal and a state judge moved to block the deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Maria Cramer, Patrick Kingsley, Robert Jimison, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: C.E.O. Shooting Suspect Arrested, and Netanyahu’s Corruption Trial
description: Plus, Google’s quantum computing breakthrough.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,271
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Dec. 11, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: A Seven-Ingredient Supper That Sings
description: Eric Kim’s roast chicken with fish-sauce butter is simple magic. (Plus: croutons.)
content: We just published our 50 most popular new recipes of 2024, the bangers of New York Times Cooking. Simplicity shines on this list, because simplicity always shines in home cooking — the promise of a recipe that is more magic than chemistry, greater than the sum of its stewed, seared or sautéed parts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camille Elemia
title: Volcanic Eruption Forces Mass Evacuation in the Philippines
description: Nearly 90,000 people on the island of Negros were ordered to seek shelter after Mount Kanlaon spewed deadly ash and lava.
content: The Philippine authorities ordered nearly 90,000 people to evacuate after a volcano on the central island of Negros erupted, spewing a two-mile-high plume of deadly ash, lava and large rocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Met Museum Unveils Design for New Modern Wing
description: The architect Frida Escobedo has drawn on her Mexican heritage in reimagining the galleries for Modern and contemporary art.
content: The metaphor of weaving has informed Frida Escobedo’s design for the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s long-awaited new wing for Modern and contemporary art, which was unveiled on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devlin Barrett
title: Review Finds Trump-Era Hunt for Leaks Extended Deep Into Congress
description: The inspector general also concluded that the department failed to follow some of its own rules when it came to seizing reporters’ communications records.
content: Leak investigations during the Trump administration extended far deeper into Congress than previously known, leading to scrutiny of the records of dozens of staff members, the Justice Department’s inspector general found in what he described as worrisome overreach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: It Wasn’t You. It Was Your Parents.
description: A decade after it was published, the book “Adult Children of Emotionally Immature Parents” is surging in popularity and making people rethink their family dynamic.
content: In 2021, Amber Nuño was living in Los Angeles, working at her dream job developing new products at Apple, making six figures and driving a nice car. On the surface, her life looked perfect, but she still felt deeply unsatisfied for reasons she couldn’t understand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Upheaval in the Middle East: A Place for Student Questions and Observations
description: Syrian rebel forces took Damascus this weekend, ending a decades-long regime and continuing a series of events that have shaken the region since Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack. Teenagers, tell us how you are making sense of the news.
content: Note: This forum is intended for teenagers. We ask that adults please comment elsewhere on nytimes.com. Teachers, please preview these materials before you share them with students to make sure they are appropriate for your class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheri Linden
title: ‘Nature of the Crime’ Review: Yearning for a Second Chance
description: Two incarcerated men navigate parole boards in a documentary that asks the question: Should the guiding principle of criminal justice be retribution or rehabilitation?
content: Peering into the heart of the beast we call the justice system, the directors Ricki Stern and Jesse Sweet zero in on parole, a part of the process that usually unfolds behind closed doors. “Nature of the Crime” offers rare glimpses of the make-or-break interviews that, in more cases than not, deny petitioners their longed-for second chance. As it traces, over a four-year period, the cycles of hope and despair for two incarcerated men — both in New York prisons for crimes committed in the state — this quiet and affecting documentary is at once an argument for reform and a soul-searching question: Should the guiding principle of criminal justice be retribution or rehabilitation?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: You Had a Lot of Questions About the Election
description: Ezra Klein answers listener questions about the future of the Democratic Party, the meaning of “the working class,” how blue cities should respond to their apparent electoral rebuke and more.
content: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing to the show on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang and David McCabe
title: Trump Picks Andrew Ferguson to Lead Federal Trade Commission
description: Mr. Ferguson, a current Republican member of the agency, will replace Lina Khan, who had aggressively challenged mergers and the power of the biggest tech companies.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Tuesday named Andrew Ferguson to lead the Federal Trade Commission, installing a current Republican member of the agency who has promised to ease up on the policing of powerful American companies — except for the biggest technology firms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Police Say Suspect in UnitedHealthcare Shooting Saw Himself as a Hero
description: The suspect’s three-page manifesto, summarized by the police, described the killing as a “symbolic takedown.”
content: The suspect in the killing of the UnitedHealthcare chief executive saw himself as a hero fighting a corrupt health insurance industry, the police said in an internal report in which they also warned about the possible threat posed by social media posts that praised the killing and encouraged similar targeted violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Wednesday Briefing: A Wave of Post-Assad Attacks
description: Plus, how Netflix brought a magical town to life.
content: Israel said that it had destroyed Syria’s navy in overnight airstrikes, as it continued to pound targets in the country despite warnings that its operations there could ignite a new conflict and jeopardize the transition to an interim government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Healy, Margie Omero and Adrian J. Rivera
title: These 14 Voters Think Trump Has One Mandate Above All, and It’s Not About the Economy
description: The group discusses abortion, immigration and what Trump should focus on in his second term.
content: The group discusses abortion, immigration and what Trump should focus on in his second term.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Justice Department’s Report
description: A two-year investigation by the agency found patterns of “outrageous” conduct by the police in Worcester, Mass., including excessive use of force and sexual contact between undercover officers and women suspected of prostitution.
content: A two-year investigation by the agency found patterns of “outrageous” conduct by the police in Worcester, Mass., including excessive use of force and sexual contact between undercover officers and women suspected of prostitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko and Claire Hogan
title: Daniel Penny Is Acquitted in Death of Jordan Neely on Subway
description: Daniel Penny, a former Marine who choked a fellow subway rider on an uptown F train last year, was acquitted on a charge of criminally negligent homicide on Monday, ending a case that had come to exemplify New York City’s post-pandemic struggles.
content: Daniel Penny, a former Marine who choked a fellow subway rider on an uptown F train last year, was acquitted on a charge of criminally negligent homicide on Monday, ending a case that had come to exemplify New York City’s post-pandemic struggles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Nikolay Nikolov, Christina Shaman and Daniel Berehulak
title: On the Ground in Damascus as Syrians Chart a New Path
description: In a matter of days, Syria’s capital — once the stronghold of Bashar al-Assad’s government — became the epicenter of a new chapter in the country’s history after opposition forces overran the city. Christina Goldbaum, a New York Times correspondent, traveled to Damascus to find out how residents were reacting to the sudden breakthrough in the 13-year civil war as more than five decades of brutal rule by the Assad dynasty come to an end.
content: In a matter of days, Syria’s capital — once the stronghold of Bashar al-Assad’s government — became the epicenter of a new chapter in the country’s history after opposition forces overran the city. Christina Goldbaum, a New York Times correspondent, traveled to Damascus to find out how residents were reacting to the sudden breakthrough in the 13-year civil war as more than five decades of brutal rule by the Assad dynasty come to an end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Faye Tsakas
title: Christmas, Every Day
description: Two preteen girls market fashion and beauty products to thousands of online fans from their Alabama home.
content: Two preteen girls market fashion and beauty products to thousands of online fans from their Alabama home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Firefighters Combat Wind-Driven Brush Fire in Malibu Canyon
description: The fast-moving blaze has burned more than 2,700 acres and forced evacuations along the California coastline north of Los Angeles.
content: The fast-moving blaze has burned more than 2,700 acres and forced evacuations along the California coastline north of Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cassel, Alessandro Pavone and Mark Boyer
title: Uncertainty and Hope on the Road to and from Damascus
description: Thousands of Syrians have been traveling to and from the Lebanese border since the fall of Bashar al-Assad’s regime. Some families hoped to reunite with loved ones, while others are leaving amid an uncertain future.
content: Thousands of Syrians have been traveling to and from the Lebanese border since the fall of Bashar al-Assad’s regime. Some families hoped to reunite with loved ones, while others are leaving amid an uncertain future.
source.name: The New York Times
